how_to_start.main_subtitle: Discover your writing style and find the perfect path to bring your story to life
how_to_start.intro: There's an old dilemma in the world of creative writing: are you a <1>gardener</1> or an <3>architect</3>? Understanding your style not only makes it easier to begin your journey, but also helps you embrace your strengths and work on your limitations.

gardener.title: The Gardener Writer
gardener.description: Like a gardener who plants seeds and watches them grow, you write by discovering the story as it unfolds. Your characters and plots reveal themselves during the writing process.

strengths.discovery: Discovery is part of the fun

challenges.lost: Risk of getting lost along the way

gardener.how_to_start_title: How to Start as a Gardener

how_to_start.write: Write your chapters freely, without overthinking at the moment. Leave improvements for later
how_to_start.characters: Create characters as they appear in your writing
how_to_start.annotations: Use annotations and links to track emerging ideas
how_to_start.dashboard: Visit the Dashboard when you feel the need to organize

architect.title: The Architect Writer
architect.description: Like an architect who draws blueprints before building, you plan every detail of your story. Your foundations are solid and every word has its defined purpose.
architect.how_to_start_title: How to Start as an Architect

how_to_start.premise: Define the premise and goals of your story
how_to_start.characters: Create complete characters with archetypes and backgrounds
how_to_start.world: Build the world with hierarchies and locations
how_to_start.plot: Map plot arcs with clear events and structure

balance.title: The Truth: You Can Be Both
balance.description: Most successful writers dance between both worlds. Some chapters sprout freely like wild gardens. Others follow meticulous blueprints. The secret isn't choosing a side, but discovering <1>when to use each approach</1>.
balance.step1_description: Write your chapters freely, letting the story flow. Use <1>editor annotations</1> or <3>draft chapters</3> to save creative ideas — from small notes to entire chapters that may be useful in the future.
balance.step2_description: After <1>10 to 20 chapters</1>, pause to review what you've written. This is the moment to put on your architect hat.
balance.step3_description: Structure characters, locations, and plot arcs. While organizing, let your <1>imagination flow</1> — create interesting future plots that can have foreshadowing from the beginning.
balance.step4_description: With a clearer structure, return to gardener mode and continue your creative journey, now with greater awareness of the whole.

power_system.main_subtitle: Use our visual tool to create a clear and organized magic or power system for your story
power_system.intro: Every fantasy world needs rules. Whether it's a complex magic system, mystical martial arts, or superpowers, the key is to <1>organize and communicate</1> those rules clearly. Our Power System tool was created for this.

basics.title: Basic and General Concepts
basics.description: Use dedicated pages to explain the fundamentals of your system. Ideal for general rules, universal laws, and concepts everyone needs to understand.

strengths.fundamentals: Fundamentals and universal laws of the system

basics.example: Create a 'Magic Fundamentals' page explaining where mana comes from, how everyone accesses it, and the three universal laws governing its use.

abilities.title: Specific Abilities
abilities.description: Create organized folders for individual abilities. The differentiator: you can <1>link each ability to specific characters</1>, visually showing who masters what.

strengths.folders: Folders by category (Fire, Healing, Illusion, etc)
strengths.visual: Clear visualization of who has each power

abilities.example: Create a 'Fire Spells' folder. Inside it, pages for 'Fireball', 'Flame Shield', 'Phoenix'. Link 'Fireball' to the character 'Arkan, the Pyromancer'.

advanced.title: Advanced Concepts
advanced.description: Reserve pages for complex mechanics, secret techniques, or aspects of the system that few master. Perfect for plot points and future revelations.
advanced.example: Create 'Ancestral Magic' with informative blocks about lost techniques. Use attribute blocks to show difficulty and danger levels.

organization.title: How to Organize Your System
organization.step1_description: Start with <1>1-2 pages of general concepts</1>. Use paragraph blocks to explain, lists for rules, and informative blocks for important warnings.
organization.step2_description: Create <1>folders for each type/school</1> of power. Inside them, one page per specific ability. Use image and icon blocks to make it visual.
organization.step3_description: For each ability, use the <1>'Manage Links'</1> button to connect to characters who master it. This creates a visual network of who can do what.
organization.step4_description: Create advanced pages as the story progresses. Use <1>navigator blocks</1> to create links between related concepts, forming an interactive wiki.
